commander.name: Console Generale Antonino Ciolfi
commander.notes: MVSN (Blackshirt militia) officer. Division named after October 28, 1922 - March on Rome. Captured at Bardia, January 5, 1941.

historical_context: 2nd CCNN Division '28 Ottobre' was one of four Blackshirt divisions deployed to North Africa. Named after the March on Rome (October 28, 1922) that brought Mussolini to power. Division participated in Italian invasion of Egypt (September 1940), retreated to Bardia fortress during Operation Compass (December 1940), and was destroyed during British assault on Bardia (January 3-5, 1941). Approximately 7,800 personnel became POWs.
personnel_notes: CCNN divisions had unusual organization: 2 legions of 3 battalions each (6 battalions total). Each battalion: 734 men. Total theoretical strength: ~7,600 combatants plus support personnel (~600-700). Snapshot taken January 3, 1941 (start of Bardia battle). Division slightly under-strength compared to 1st CCNN Division.

2.notes: Squad automatic weapon, 6.5x52mm (48 per legion x 2 legions + extras)

L3/35 Tankette.notes: XLII Light Tank Battalion - 3 companies of 15 L3/35 each (45 total authorized), actual strength ~18 operational

tanks.notes: XLII Light Tank Battalion attached. L3/35 tankettes were two-man vehicles with twin 8mm machine guns. Completely inadequate against British Matilda II and Crusader tanks. Most destroyed or captured during Bardia battle.

65mm/17 Infantry Gun.notes: Legion Gun Batteries - 4 guns per legion x 2 legions

75mm/27 Field Gun.notes: 202nd Artillery Regiment - 2 Gruppi of 12 guns each

47mm/32 Mod. 35.notes: 2nd CCNN Anti-Tank Company - 4 gun platoons of 2 guns each

45mm Brixia.notes: Battalion mortars - 9 per battalion x 6 battalions (reduced from authorized strength)

81mm Mortar.notes: Legion Mortar Companies - 6 per legion x 2 legions

Light trucks.notes: Various light trucks from legion and support units

pack_animals.notes: 206 mules per legion x 2 legions. Critical for ammunition and supply transport in rough terrain.

ground_vehicles_notes: CCNN divisions had fewer vehicles than regular army divisions. Limited mobility. Many vehicles abandoned or destroyed during Bardia battle. Slightly fewer trucks than 1st CCNN Division due to attrition.
aircraft_notes: Division had no organic aircraft. Air support (when available) provided by Regia Aeronautica under separate command.

subordinate_units.notes: Three-battalion legion structure unique to CCNN divisions

composition: 3 MG Companies (each: HQ + 4 Platoons with 16 HMG total)
subordinate_units.notes: Heavy machine gun battalion - 72 heavy machine guns total. Provided division-level fire support.

composition: 4 Gun Platoons (2 x 47/32 ATk guns each)
subordinate_units.notes: 8 x 47mm anti-tank guns. Inadequate against British Matilda II heavy infantry tanks.

composition: I Gruppo (12 x 100/17 Howitzers) - reduced to 4 guns actual
subordinate_units.notes: Army artillery regiment attached to CCNN division. Standard Italian organization.
Authorized 49 L3/35 tankettes, actual strength ~19. Under-strength due to mechanical failures and combat losses.

supply_logistics.supply_status: Poor - besieged in Bardia fortress alongside 1st CCNN Division. Cut off from main supply lines. Relying on pre-positioned stores within fortress. Water adequate from wells. Fuel critically low (immobilizing vehicles). Ammunition stocks declining under British bombardment. No resupply possible.

weather_environment.terrain_type: coastal plain with rocky escarpment and fortress positions

operational_readiness.personnel_status: Moderate - trapped in fortress, morale declining
operational_readiness.equipment_status: Poor - fuel shortages, limited ammunition, vehicles mostly immobilized
operational_readiness.morale: Low - surrounded, no relief expected, continuous British bombardment, aware of defeats elsewhere
operational_readiness.notes: Division effectively destroyed January 3-5, 1941 during British assault on Bardia. Approximately 7,800 personnel captured. Division never reformed.

known_issues: CCNN divisions less well-trained than regular army divisions
Political appointees as officers (often less militarily competent)
Inadequate anti-tank weapons (47mm ineffective vs Matilda II)
Weak armor support (L3 tankettes obsolete and vulnerable)
Low morale - militia forces facing professional British/Commonwealth troops
Divided loyalty - Blackshirts loyal to Fascist Party, not always to Army command
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Minimal. Division struggled with desert environment. Fortified positions at Bardia provided some protection but limited maneuverability and adaptation to mobile warfare.

special_rules: Poor anti-tank capability (-2 vs heavy tanks)
Militia training penalty (-1 vs regular troops)
Fascist fanaticism (may ignore first failed morale check)
historical_engagements: Italian invasion of Egypt (September 1940) - Advance to Sidi Barrani
Retreat from Egypt (December 1940) - Withdrawal to Bardia
Battle of Bardia (January 3-5, 1941) - Defeat, ~7,800 POWs, division destroyed
